context: The public's understanding of what drones are and do is woefully ignorant.  Can't tell you how many times someone thought I was spying on them because they could see and hear my drone a 100+ feet up.   I'd show them the pics and video I'm taking and that normally puts their fears to rest.  Most drones that high up can't zoom in like that.  Unless it's hovering outside your window, it's likely the drone operator is NOT spying people.

replies.context: Attach your cell phone to it.
Spying or not, the neighbors will think you‚Äôre a creep.
That's their problem, not mine.  I promise you, they'll think me a creep anyways if they shoot down my $1,000+ drone.  I'll draw blood for that.

So they shoot down your toy flying over their backyard and YOU will "draw blood?"  LOL sounds like YOU are the one looking at a felony.  Have some respect for people's privacy and you won't risk losing your investment.

Have some respect for other people's property and you won't lose your worthless head over it.  I work hard to earn that money.  If the courts don't rectify it to my satisfaction, then I will and I promise it'll cost the person shooting down the drone a LOT more than what I paid for my drone.

My, but you're a childish sort, aren't you? You fly your little toy, spying over people's houses and expect them not to be concerned? Guess what? If your toy gets shot down, the same gun will defend that person when they see you prancing across the yard wigging out. Grow up and learn some respect.
Feel free to fly it over my property.   I'll destroy it and then you when you come looking for blood.
I will and you won't do a thing about it tough guy.  Lets test it.  Give me your address and I'll come over and fly it :-)
You know what, neighbors already pee me off!

The article didn't mention the "spying" aspect of drones. It's the noise the drones make that are spooking the pets, as well as cutting way down on quality of life for those in the drone's flight path.
Wow, the fact that you don't know how to get that done does not mean other people won't, especially the ones with lots of money, like drug lords, for example.

You talking spying?   Unless you are up to no good, there's really very little reason anyone would try and spy with a drone.  As the article says, they are loud which is a dead give away, especially at low altitudes which is where you can actually see enough to spy.
What about spying just for the fun of looking at neighbors doing their thing? You never know what you can catch on camera. Believe me, image zooming will not be a problem.

I suppose there are some that do that but again, the noise gives it away.  You can see more with a nice pair of binoculars and the person would be totally clueless it's happening.  I suppose a few would abuse it, but most don't and try hard to follow the ever increasing regulations that the FAA puts on their use.  Most of the time I use it on vacation or when I see a nice landscape shot I can get.  Again, someone with a regular camera and telephoto lens can do the same thing, just a different angle and the residents around would be clueless.  At least with a drone, you know it's there and you can choose not to do anything you don't want someone to see.  With a telephoto lens, you don't know that.

Yes, a commercial drone delivery I can see that being a problem.  But hobbiests like me get irritated when someone tries to destroy my property for no other reason then they are irritated because they can hear or see it.   I'm just taking landscape photos and they have no right to destroy my property.   From talking to people who are irritated, I find a lot think it's because I can see things I can't with it.   Most aren't bothered by the noise when it's 200-400 feet up.
What's your address then tough guy.  Can't fly it over your property if I don't know where you are.  Come on keyboard warrior, cough it up Nancy.

If someone is comparing the sound of a drone to the sound of a chain saw "gone ballistic", they are exaggerating a little.  No, they are not quiet, but they aren't that loud either.  Once they get above 250 ft., they are difficult to hear at all and are about the same as a small plane flying overhead at 1500 ft.

Also, unless local sound ordinances are violated, homeowners will have difficulty fighting this.  Plus, the actual deliveries would last about 2 minutes out of your day.  How much annoyance can that really be.

Before you try to damage one or shoot one down, check your local laws and then check with the FAA.  You may find you are going to be the one in trouble.

How well does a drone fly with Silly String lodged in its propellers?

replies.context: The larger ones will cut right through the silly string.  The propellers can do serious damage or remove fingers.  The smaller one's don't handle this type obstruction well, but it'll take something more that silly string to bring a delivery drone down.
